author: By Erik Piepenburg
title: ‘Sublime’ Review: Two Boys, One in Love
description: A teenager dreams of pop songs, and his best friend, in Mariano Biasin’s tender gay coming-of-age drama.
content: In high school I had a crush on my best friend. I sat with him when he played piano in church. I was furious inside when he told me he liked a girl. When I came out to him in college he said “so what?” and I cried. Tweak some details and switch the setting from suburban America to a coastal town in Argentina and it’s also the entire plot of Mariano Biasin’s familiar but muted coming-out drama “Sublime.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson and Jackie Molloy
title: A Brooklyn School Pioneers New Ways to Teach Children With Disabilities
description: At P.S. 15 in Red Hook, a unique program for students with intellectual disabilities could serve as a model for other New York City schools.
content: The third graders in Room 221 began their day with a chain of hugs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: China Cuts Key Interest Rates, Hoping to Kick-Start Flagging Economy
description: The reduction in the rates, which are used to set corporate loans and home mortgages, signaled concern that the country’s postpandemic rebound was stalling.
content: China’s central bank cut key interest rates on Tuesday for loans issued by the state-controlled banking system, in the clearest sign yet of mounting concern in the Chinese government and corporate sector that the country’s economy is stalling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Today’s Top News: The Blinken-Xi Meeting, and More
description: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
content: The New York Times Audio app includes podcasts, narrated articles from the newsroom and other publishers, as well as exclusive new shows — including this one — which we’re making available to readers for a limited time. Download the audio app here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: An Alternative to Increasingly Elusive Bottles of Chartreuse
description: A San Francisco amaro company offers Chaparral, the owner of La Boîte publishes a Middle Eastern pantry primer and more food news.
content: As OPEC does with oil, the Carthusian monastery that has made Chartreuse liqueurs in Eastern France since 1605 is limiting the flow of the spirit and causing shortages at the bar. (The monks do not plan to increase production to meet demand; better to concentrate on solitude and prayer.) Though the venerable liqueur has a unique recipe, there’s a promising alternative for that Last Word cocktail: Chaparral. It’s one of three amaros by Brucato Amaro, a San Francisco company specializing in that category of drink, all inspired by the California landscape. A base of California brandy is infused with yerba santa, mint, anise and cardamom, resulting in a greenish-amber liqueur scented with warm spices and cool mint, slightly sweet and decidedly herbal on the palate. It’s a little less green and syrupy, but can step into a cocktail without missing a beat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By H. Claire Brown
title: A Job With a Fair Salary? What Pay Transparency Laws Are Revealing.
description: Salary disclosure laws have been a boon for workers searching for jobs that pay fairly — but only when the advertised pay bands are narrow enough to be useful.
content: Last December, Yun Yati Naing began searching for the job she would begin after graduating from Baruch College in New York City. It was one month after a law passed by the city went into effect requiring employers with four or more employees to post salary ranges on all new job advertisements.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason DeParle
title: Federal Policy on Homelessness Becomes New Target of the Right
description: The approach known as Housing First has long enjoyed bipartisan support. But conservatives are pushing efforts to replace it with programs that put more emphasis on sobriety and employment.
content: The bipartisan approach that has dominated federal homelessness policy for more than two decades is under growing conservative attack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen O'Connor
title: What Happens When You Get So Influential That You’re Bored by Your Own Aesthetic?
description: In search of a refresh, Athena Calderone, the queen of muted Brooklyn interiors, is moving to Manhattan. She almost went broke renovating the townhouse that cemented her place in the interiors world.
content: Athena Calderone wanted to move, but she had a problem: The home she already had was perfect.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melena Ryzik
title: Ebon Moss-Bachrach Gives ‘The Bear’ Its Abrasive Edge
description: This thoughtful Brooklyn dad excels at playing stunted men like Richie, his volatile character in the FX hit. Just don’t call them dirtbags: “I get a little sensitive,” he said.
content: The joke on the set of “The Bear,” the hit FX series about a faltering Chicago restaurant, is that there are two Ebon Moss-Bachrachs: New York Ebon and Chicago Ebon. And they are very different.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Salam
title: Elton John Warns of ‘Growing Swell of Anger and Homophobia’ in U.S.
description: “We seem to be going backwards,” the pop superstar warned as he lamented the curtailing of L.G.B.T.Q. rights in the United States, particularly in Florida.
content: The British pop superstar Elton John lamented the “growing swell of anger and homophobia” in the United States and described several laws recently passed in Florida that curtail L.G.B.T.Q. rights as “disgraceful.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor
title: Titan Pilot Is a Booster of Deep-Sea Tourism
description: Stockton Rush, the chief executive of OceanGate Expeditions, is one of the five occupants of the missing submersible.
content: Stockton Rush, the chief executive of OceanGate Expeditions and one of the five occupants of the submersible missing this week in the North Atlantic, has advocated for deep-seas tourism in the face of criticism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: Return to Office Enters the Desperation Phase
description: The next stage of getting workers back at their desks includes incentives like $10 to the charity of their choice — and consequences like poor performance evaluations if they don’t make the trek in.
content: Manny Medina, the chief executive of a Seattle-based artificial intelligence sales company, doesn’t mind repeating himself. It comes with the territory, after all. That tolerance proved convenient this year as he faced the same question innumerable times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pam Belluck and Emily Bazelon
title: New York Passes Bill to Shield Abortion Providers Sending Pills Into States With Bans
description: The measure is one of several recently enacted by states aiming to expand access to medication abortion for patients who live where it is outlawed.
content: The New York State Legislature gave final approval on Tuesday to legislation that provides legal protection for New York doctors to prescribe and send abortion pills to patients in states that have outlawed abortion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs, Jenny Gross and Anna Betts
title: OceanGate Was Warned of Potential for ‘Catastrophic’ Problems With Titanic Mission
description: Experts inside and outside the company warned of potential dangers and urged the company to undergo a certification process.
content: Years before OceanGate’s submersible craft went missing in the Atlantic Ocean with five people onboard, the company faced several warnings as it prepared for its hallmark mission of taking wealthy passengers to tour the Titanic’s wreckage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Business Lessons From Blinken’s Trip to China
description: The secretary of state’s talks with Xi Jinping raised hopes that the world’s two biggest economies might stabilize relations, but the big challenges were not resolved.
content: Worries about China’s economic recovery sent stocks and U.S. futures lower on Tuesday morning, despite a promising meeting on Monday between the country’s top leader, Xi Jinping, and Secretary of State Antony Blinken in Beijing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Attention-Grabbing Shouts
description: Take a deep breath and let it out for this lovely puzzle by Aimee Lucido.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall and Daniel Berehulak
title: ‘They Expected Me to Die on My Own’: Life as a Ukrainian P.O.W.
description: Ukrainian captives released in prisoner exchanges say that beatings were common, and that they suffered from woefully inadequate health care and food.
content: Shot through the jaw and tongue by a sniper’s bullet last year in the last days of the grinding siege at the Azovstal steel plant in Ukraine, Senior Sgt. Maksym Kushnir could not eat or talk, and could barely breathe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Paxton Whitehead, Actor Who Found Humor in the Stodgy, Dies at 85
description: An Englishman with a deep, cultured voice, he played uptight snobs in films like “Back to School” and on shows like “Friends” and “Mad About You.”
content: Paxton Whitehead, a comic actor who earned a Tony nomination for his role in a revival of “Camelot” and played the starchiest of stuffed shirts in films like the Rodney Dangerfield comedy “Back to School” and on hit 1990s sitcoms like “Friends” and “Mad About You,” died on Friday in Arlington, Va. He was 85.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: TUESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: The Search for a Missing Titanic Tour Sub
description: Also, Hunter Biden agrees to plead guilty. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
content: The U.S. Coast Guard was racing against time today to find a deep-diving submersible with five people on board two days after it went missing in the North Atlantic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: John Corbett Knows What You Want From Him
description: He was defined by his role in “Sex and the City,” not always comfortably. He’s reprising it in “And Just Like That …” because “I’ve made friends with the idea of, this is just what I do.”
content: Over the years, people have cornered John Corbett on the street, at the grocery store, in coffee shops, to swear fealty. “Every [expletive] person I meet is just, ‘I was Team Aidan!’” he said. He assumes that those people are lying.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jac Jemc
title: In Clémence Michallon’s Debut, a Serial Killer Deceives an Entire Town
description: “The Quiet Tenant” offers multiple perspectives on a monster who keeps his victim and his young daughter under the same roof.
content: Clémence Michallon’s assured debut, “The Quiet Tenant,” is an expertly paced psychological thriller that follows three female characters, each compelled and controlled in different ways by the same man.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: The aftermath of a devastating shipwreck in Greece.
content: A decision by the Greek Coast Guard not to intervene in a deadly shipwreck has raised concerns that an alignment of interests between smugglers, who are paid to reach Italy, and the Greek authorities, who would rather the migrants be Italy’s problem, led to an avoidable catastrophe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Kisselgoff
title: Magda Saleh, Influential Egyptian Ballerina, Is Dead at 79
description: Trained at the Bolshoi, she became a star of the Cairo Ballet and played a key role in making ballet accessible to people of all classes.
content: Magda Saleh, a Bolshoi-trained Egyptian ballerina who was a star of the Cairo Ballet and played a major role in introducing ballet to wider audiences in her country, and who then served as director of the company’s ballet school and of a new opera house, died on June 11 in Cairo. She was 79.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Zraick
title: 3 Are Convicted of Harassing Family on Behalf of China’s Government
description: The defendants, including a private detective who said he did not realize he was working for an intelligence operation, pursued people living in New Jersey.
content: Three men were convicted in Brooklyn federal court on Tuesday of stalking a family in the New Jersey suburbs on behalf of the Chinese government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael S. Schmidt and Adam Entous
title: Hunter Biden Reaches Deal to Plead Guilty to Misdemeanor Tax Charges
description: Under an agreement with the Justice Department, the president’s son agreed to probation for filing his taxes late, and he can avoid a charge that he lied about his drug use when he bought a gun.
content: Hunter Biden agreed with the Justice Department on Tuesday to plead guilty to two misdemeanor tax charges and accept terms that would allow him to avoid prosecution on a separate gun charge, a big step toward ending a long-running and politically explosive investigation into the finances, drug use and international business dealings of President Biden’s troubled son.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Ocasio-Cortez’s Unusual Place in N.Y. City Council Races: The Sidelines
description: With early voting in the New York City Council primaries underway, Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez has yet to endorse any candidate.
content: Two years ago, Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez set out to put her imprint on New York City government, using her personal clout and a leadership PAC to boost dozens of left-leaning candidates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenna Russell
title: Rescuers Ramp Up Efforts to Find Craft Missing en Route to Titanic Wreckage
description: Coast Guard and international crews redoubled their efforts to find the missing Titan watercraft, amid growing worries about how long the air supply would last deep underwater.
content: With alarm rising and air supply onboard the missing watercraft dwindling, a growing array of international rescuers ramped up their search on Tuesday for the submersible carrying five people that disappeared on Sunday while en route to the wreckage of the Titanic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophie Ward
title: Sex, Identity and the Eternal Anxieties of Growing Up
description: In Haley Jakobson’s compassionate debut novel, “Old Enough,” a college sophomore must navigate her first steps into young adulthood while unpacking the trauma of past abuse.
content: There’s a popular Japanese television show called “Old Enough” that challenges preschool children to perform daily tasks without the help of an adult. The tension lies in watching the child come to terms with their mission and their fears; the joy is in witnessing the child’s profound sense of achievement and the parents’ relief and pride. In Haley Jakobson’s debut novel, “Old Enough,” readers may experience similar feelings while following a 19-year-old bisexual college sophomore, Savannah Henry, as she embarks on a haphazard quest to leave her childhood and trauma behind. We want her to succeed, but we all know growing up isn’t easy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Bogard
title: We’re Watching the Sky as We Know It Disappear
description: The sky has enormous power to shape our lives and to signal how disrupted our climate is becoming.
content: MINNEAPOLIS — The first day in early June when my 5-year-old and I camped in Minnesota’s lake country was the usual heaven — perfect calm for canoeing, an osprey overhead as we braved a swim in the cold spring water and a clear blue sky.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Eblen
title: The Hotel That Started as a Gift Shop
description: Shannon Maldonado quit her job in fashion design to open a home-goods store, Yowie. Now she’s opening a Yowie hotel where nearly all the décor is for sale.
content: When she was growing up, Shannon Maldonado wanted to be a fashion designer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Miller
title: One More Chorus of ‘Humm Baby’ for a Baseball Lifer
description: At a memorial service for Roger Craig, a writer recalls time spent with a player, coach and manager who connected generations of baseball history.
content: On the fringe of a quiet golf course in the foothills outside San Diego, music from the Highwaymen galloped from the sound system. Family and baseball, inextricably intertwined, had gathered to say one final goodbye to Roger Craig. Horses and golf, two other staples in this North Carolina country boy’s life, gracefully filled the green pastures and dusty trails of the imagination as the songs rang out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian X. Chen
title: Final Fantasy XVI Takes on Its ‘Star Wars’ Problem
description: Square Enix is trying to make a role-playing game for old fans and new gamers alike, a precarious tightrope for aging franchises.
content: Whenever a new Final Fantasy arrives, fans of the role-playing video games that became famous in the 1990s for using the medium to tell deep, epic stories with large, diverse casts hope that this will be the one to make the franchise relevant again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Vadukul
title: But Would They Really Go Back to the Jazz Age?
description: A lawn party for would-be Gatsbys and flappers has become an annual New York tradition.
content: Hundreds of time travelers in 1920s-era outfits took ferries to Governors Island earlier this month to attend the two-day Jazz Age Lawn Party, one of New York City’s most curious summer traditions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: Restaurant Review: Okdongsik Serves Two Things, and Both Are Outstanding
description: The tiny counter from one of South Korea’s star chefs is a near-replica of its counterpart in Seoul.
content: I don’t think I ever understood how any meat broth could be the basis of a restaurant’s reputation until I ate the dweji gomtang at Okdongsik.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kayla Guo
title: Republicans, Claiming Double Standard, Vow to Keep Investigating Bidens
description: Congressional Republicans accused President Biden of orchestrating a lenient penalty for his son, while Democrats argued that bringing any charges reflected the Justice Department’s independence.
content: Congressional Republicans on Tuesday blasted the plea deal Hunter Biden reached with the Justice Department, accusing President Biden of orchestrating a lenient penalty for his son and promising to intensify their investigations of the Biden family.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: Two of the Passengers Are a Prominent Businessman and His 19-Year-Old Son
description: Shahzada Dawood and his son, Suleman, are aboard the missing submersible.
content: The British businessman Shahzada Dawood, 48, and his son, Suleman, 19, are aboard the missing submersible, according to a statement from the Engro Corporation, based in Karachi, Pakistan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anjali Huynh
title: How Trump Has Tried to Use Hunter Biden as a Way to Attack His Father
description: Donald Trump has for years depicted Hunter Biden as corrupt and used unsubstantiated claims to link his Democratic rival to his son’s business dealings.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump has been among the most insistent of Republican voices seeking to use Hunter Biden as a way to discredit his father, President Biden — and the guilty plea on Tuesday quickly became yet another point of attack as Mr. Trump seeks the Republican presidential nomination for a third time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenna Russell
title: With Pandemic Aid Ending, Vermont’s Homeless Are Forced From Hotels
description: The state has begun emptying hotels of about 2,800 homeless people living there as part of a pandemic-era program — and offering them tents — after federal funding ran out.
content: As his few remaining hours with a place to live ticked by last Thursday, Scott Alexander panhandled near a McDonald’s in Brattleboro, in southern Vermont, while running through a mental checklist of the supplies he would need for a move back into the woods nearby.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Readers’ Picks: 12 Pride Anthems
description: A playlist with personal stories about the ways music plays a vital role in struggles, triumphs and self-expression.
content: A few weeks ago, I asked you to submit songs to help create the ultimate Pride playlist. As usual, you delivered. Big time.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: June 20, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, June 20, 2023.
content: A picture caption with an article on June 13 about NATO members conducting major air exercises in Germany as a signal of allied strength against Russia’s invasion of Ukraine misidentified a fighter jet. The jet shown is a Saab Gripen, not a Eurofighter Typhoon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Abrams
title: A Teen Basketball Star Took His Time Growing Up for the N.B.A.
description: Scoot Henderson finished high school early to start a two-year apprenticeship for the N.B.A. Now, at 19, his moment has arrived.
content: His lungs were on fire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Cohen
title: The U.K. moves to use frozen Russian assets to help Ukraine rebuild.
description: The government’s announcement follows a pledge made by Group of 7 nations at their annual gathering last month to freeze Russian assets until Moscow pays for the damage done in Ukraine.
content: As Russia’s ruinous attacks on Ukraine mount, Britain’s government is proposing legislation that would enable it to divert frozen Russian assets to the rebuilding of Ukraine and keep sanctions in place until Moscow pays compensation to its war-torn neighbor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: Jonathan Majors to Face Trial on Assault Charges in August
description: The movie star, who has maintained his innocence, appeared briefly in a Manhattan courtroom on Tuesday morning.
content: The actor Jonathan Majors appeared in a Manhattan courtroom on Tuesday morning at a brief hearing where a trial date for his misdemeanor assault case was set for August.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Republicans Against Inequality
description: We’re covering a new breed of Republicans, a missing submersible near the Titanic and Judge Judy’s new TV empire.
content: A rising generation of Republican politicians is more skeptical of the free market and more comfortable using government power to regulate the economy than the party has traditionally been. Consider:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Betts
title: OceanGate Expeditions Was Created to Explore Deep Waters
description: The company has made headlines for organizing expeditions for paying tourists to travel in submersibles to shipwrecks, including the Titanic.
content: OceanGate Expeditions, the owner of the missing submersible, is a privately owned company headquartered in Everett, Wash., that, since its founding in 2009, has focused on increasing access to deep-ocean exploration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Shop Owner Who Paid Ex-Worker in Pennies Is Ordered to Pay More
description: A federal judge issued a consent judgment that requires the auto shop owner to pay more than $39,000 for retaliating against the former worker and for failing to pay overtime to employees.
content: A court in Georgia has ordered the owner of an auto-repair shop who disbursed a former employee’s wages with about 91,500 greasy pennies left in his driveway to pay nearly $40,000 in back pay and damages. The judgment said that the shop owner retaliated against the worker, who had asked for his final paycheck, and that he failed to pay overtime to the man and eight other employees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman, Alan Feuer and Jonathan Swan
title: Trump Says ‘Secret’ Document He Described on Tape Referred to News Clippings
description: “There was no document,” the former president said on Fox News as he gave some of his most expansive remarks on the case that led to his federal indictment.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump claimed to a Fox News anchor in an interview on Monday that he did not have a classified document with him in a meeting with a book publisher even though he referred during that meeting to “secret” information in his possession.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff
title: E.U. Takes Aim at China in Proposed Economic Strategy
description: A European Commission plan seeks to bar companies from sending sensitive high-tech goods to potentially hostile countries — without naming any names.
content: The European Commission on Tuesday unveiled a new trade doctrine aimed at curbing China’s ability to squeeze Europe’s economy, and at preventing European companies from exporting sensitive, military-linked technology that could give China an edge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: sabotage
description: This word has appeared in 311 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word sabotage has appeared in 311 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on March 17 in the obituary “Simone Segouin, Teenage Fighter in French Resistance, Dies at 97” by Richard Sandomir:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Allen
title: ‘It Has It All’: Taking on a Strange, Immense Piano Concerto
description: The conductor Esa-Pekka Salonen and the pianist Igor Levit discuss Ferruccio Busoni’s Piano Concerto, a rarity they are performing in San Francisco.
content: There are piano concertos, and then there is Ferruccio Busoni’s Piano Concerto.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: For Biden, the Troubles of His Son Are Personal and Politically Painful
description: Hunter Biden’s plea agreement put him in the cross-hairs of President Biden’s adversaries once again.
content: After more than a half-century in politics, no subject may be more personally painful nor politically problematic for President Biden than his troubled son, Hunter. He is by various accounts a gaping wound in his heart and the most sensitive soft spot in his campaign armor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: Gannett Sues Google, Accusing It of Dominating the Ad Market
description: The country’s largest newspaper chain said Google’s power over ad technology has contributed to the decline of local news.
content: Gannett, the country’s largest newspaper chain, filed a lawsuit against Google on Tuesday, accusing the tech giant of violating federal antitrust laws by illegally abusing a monopoly over the technology used by publishers to buy and sell online ads.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manuela Andreoni
title: Someone to Know: A Lawyer for Forests
description: Democratic institutions are reeling in India. Meet the environmental lawyer who is still using them to protect nature.
content: President Biden is welcoming Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India to the White House this week. They want to show the world that the two largest democracies are strengthening their alliance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson and Christopher Kuo
title: Tony Awards Give a Box Office Boost to Prize-Winning Shows
description: “Leopoldstadt,” which was named best play, and “Kimberly Akimbo,” which won best musical, saw considerable increases in ticket sales.
content: “Leopoldstadt” and “Kimberly Akimbo,” the two shows that took home top Tony Awards last week, saw big bumps at the box office in the days following that ceremony.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Coscarelli
title: Morgan Wallen’s ‘One Thing’ Returns to No. 1 for the 13th Time
description: The country singer’s latest album has topped the Billboard chart for more than half the year.
content: Nearly halfway through the year, Morgan Wallen has spent most of it on top.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hurubie Meko, Chelsia Rose Marcius, Winnie Hu and Ellen Yan
title: 4 Die in Fire Caused by Batteries in E-Bike Shop Near Chinatown
description: The blaze, which left two others in critical condition, began on the first floor of a building at 80 Madison Street shortly after midnight.
content: Four people died Tuesday morning in a fire caused by lithium-ion batteries, just the latest in a series of fatal blazes in New York as delivery people in the convenience-addicted city increasingly rely on electric vehicles.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Life and Courage of Daniel Ellsberg, ‘a True American Hero’
description: Readers express gratitude for the risk he took in leaking the Pentagon Papers. Also: Maternal health; the 2024 election; reasons for hope; diversity in orchestras.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yonette Joseph and Anna Betts
title: What to Know About the Missing Titan Submersible and the Race to Find It
description: U.S. and Canadian crews are searching for the 22-foot vessel with five people aboard, bound for the Titanic shipwreck site, that has been missing since Sunday.
content: A submersible watercraft with five people on board has been missing since shortly after it set out on Sunday to explore the site of the Titanic shipwreck in the North Atlantic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cassandra Vinograd and Victoria Kim
title: Russia Targets Kyiv and Lviv With Attack Drones
description: Moscow’s forces also shot and killed a rescue worker in the flood-stricken city of Kherson, Ukrainian officials said, as both sides battled for territory in the south and east.
content: Russia unleashed dozens of attack drones across Ukraine before dawn on Tuesday, targeting the cities of Kyiv and Lviv, far from the front lines where Ukraine’s counteroffensive made small gains and Russian forces tried to seize more territory in eastern Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Willy Chavarria
title: We Are Beauty; We Are Dignity
description: Our clothing signals who we are, and how we want to be perceived.
content: This essay is part of a series called The Big Ideas, in which writers respond to a single question: Who do you think you are? You can read more by visiting The Big Ideas series page.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: What Republicans Say About Their Risky Balancing Act on Abortion
description: The historic Dobbs ruling has hurt the party electorally, but G.O.P. lawmakers are still moving to pass more restrictive laws. These two realities represent the defining political fallout of the end of Roe v. Wade.
content: In the year since the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade, one of the country’s most emotionally charged issues has come to be defined by two seemingly contradictory political realities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: Proceeds of Chelsea Sale Have Yet to Reach Any Ukraine War Victims
description: A $3.1 billion fund was established when Roman Abramovich was forced to sell the club, but the fund’s head says a “bureaucratic quagmire” has kept the money frozen.
content: It was the biggest price paid for a soccer team, and for a while the biggest price paid for a sports team anywhere in the world. And the enormous proceeds were to create what would be one of the biggest humanitarian charities ever established.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Pierson and Edward Wong
title: Blinken Visit Reveals Chasm in How U.S. and China Perceive Rivalry
description: Xi Jinping and nationalistic Chinese see recent U.S. actions as an effort to contain another superpower rather than compete with it — and they’re pushing back.
content: An austere greeting on the airport tarmac in Beijing sans a red carpet. A stone-faced handshake from China’s top foreign policy official. A seat looking up at the Chinese leader, Xi Jinping, perched at the head of a long table.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: In ‘A Simulacrum,’ Steve Cuiffo Has Nothing Up His Sleeves
description: The magician worked with the playwright Lucas Hnath to create “a more vulnerable version of magic performance,” Hnath said.
content: Steve Cuiffo began performing magic the way that most kids do. His brother did tricks. So did an older cousin. A grandfather had a routine with a handkerchief and a dime that absolutely killed. While he was in elementary school, he started entertaining at birthday parties, first for $5 and then more. He kept up his routines even as he studied theater at New York University and began to work with avant-garde companies like the Wooster Group.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Rachelle Bonja, Will Reid, Rob Szypko, Lisa Chow, M.J. Davis Lin, Chris Wood, Dan Powell and Marion Lozano
title: Inflation Is Way Down. Is It by Design or Just Luck?
description: Falling prices for gas and groceries have been a big help to the Federal Reserve.
content: Rapid inflation has been a problem in the United States for more than two years, but the tide appears to be turning.  Annual inflation is now less than half of what it was last summer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: Creating an Outdoor Kitchen Is Easier Than You Think
description: That grill you’ve got in the backyard? With a little help, you can turn it into something more.
content: One of the great pleasures of summer is grilling food outside, over an open flame. If you’re fortunate enough to have some space outdoors, your grill can become more than just a place to flip burgers. With a little design help, you can turn it into an outdoor kitchen — and the center of all your outdoor entertaining.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Palestinian Gunmen Kill 4 Israeli Civilians in Occupied West Bank
description: Two Hamas members carried out the attack outside Eli, a settlement in the northern West Bank, before being shot dead themselves.
content: Two Palestinian gunmen shot and killed four Israeli civilians on Tuesday afternoon outside a Jewish settlement in the Israeli-occupied West Bank, the Israeli military said, in the deadliest attack on Israelis since January.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer, Maggie Haberman and Charlie Savage
title: Judge in Trump Documents Case Sets Tentative Trial Date as Soon as August
description: The judge, Aileen M. Cannon, set an aggressive schedule for moving the case forward, though the proceedings are likely to be delayed by pretrial clashes.
content: The federal judge presiding over the prosecution of former President Donald J. Trump in the classified documents case set an aggressive schedule on Tuesday, ordering a trial to begin as soon as Aug. 14.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson and Benjamin Mueller
title: Collective Force of Head Hits, Not Just the Number of Them, Increases Odds of C.T.E.
description: The largest study of chronic traumatic encephalopathy to date found that the cumulative force of head hits absorbed by players in their careers is the best predictor of future brain disease.
content: When Jeffrey Vlk played running back in high school in the 1990s and then safety in college, he took and delivered countless tackles during full-contact football practices. Hitting was a mainstay, as were injuries, including concussions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: SushiDelic Embraces Kawaii With Neon Pink Styling and Individual Sushi Bites
description: More sushi openings, a sibling for Gertie and other restaurant news.
content: Sushi’s umbrella shelters many options, from the nearly ceremonial progression by revered master chefs to ready-made at the supermarket. For Sebastian Masuda, a Japanese artist and designer, sushi gives free rein to kawaii, the cutesy component of Japanese culture. On a block that is also home to Flour Shop’s colorful baked goods, his neon-pink sushi restaurant fits right in. Enormous grinning cats dangle from the ceiling, lights look like tubes of lipstick and a sinuous conveyor belt at a 18-seat counter delivers portions of sushi made with tuna and pink rice on savory turquoise macarons; tempura served with a palette of bright dips; and chirashi dappled with beads of salmon roe and piled into a parfait glass. The food on the conveyor is interspersed with Mr. Masuda’s playful, glittering sculptures of sushi and stilettos. Six courses are $85. Table seats are available indoors and out. Mr. Masuda calls it the “new generation of sushi,” as entertaining as it is tasty. The chef, Kyle Puchir, is a Daniel alum. There are also options for takeout, including individual sushi bites wrapped in cellophane like candy. Hiro Nishida, a restaurateur, manages the venture, and Taka Tanaka, whose company Autec makes sushi robots, is a partner. (Opens June 28)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Mastroianni
title: Your Brain Has Tricked You Into Thinking Everything Is Worse
description: Our biased attention means we’ll always feel we’re living in dark times, and our biased memory means we’ll always think the past was brighter.
content: Perhaps no political promise is more potent or universal than the vow to restore a golden age. From Caesar Augustus to the Medicis and Adolf Hitler, from President Xi Jinping of China and President “Bongbong” Marcos of the Philippines to Donald Trump’s “Make America Great Again” and Joe Biden’s “America Is Back,” leaders have gained power by vowing a return to the good old days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: When Submersibles Meet the Titanic, James Cameron Is an Inspiration
description: Cameron’s 1997 movie “Titanic” reinvigorated interest in the ill-fated ocean liner, feeding the mystique that spurs some wealthy experience chasers.
content: James Cameron, the Academy Award-winning movie director behind “Titanic,” knows about the risks of deep ocean exploration. A seasoned underwater explorer himself, in 2012 he prepared to plummet nearly seven miles to the world’s deepest known ocean trench.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz and Orlando Mayorquin
title: Idaho Man Is Charged With Murdering 4 Neighbors
description: The shooting came days after the suspect’s family accused one of the victims of indecent exposure, according to an affidavit signed by a state police detective.
content: An Idaho man has been charged with four counts of first-degree murder and one count of burglary after breaking into a neighbor’s home and fatally shooting four people, prosecutors said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: The Dirty (and Grassy) Secrets Behind the Home Field Advantage
description: In an era of expertly manicured fields and shared knowledge among groundskeepers, crews have an unexpected tool in their arsenal: the ban on infield shifts.
content: Greg Elliott, the forward-thinking head groundskeeper for the San Francisco Giants, flies a drone over the pristine grass at Oracle Park five days a week. The device is equipped with an infrared camera that measures the stress levels and overall health of the turf. In the first two months of this season, Elliott had detected a notable difference from the previous two years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erika Solomon
title: German Spy Agency Says China and Russia Are After Its Secrets
description: The country is a growing target for foreign espionage, the agency said, amid rising tensions over the war in Ukraine and rivalries between Washington and Beijing.
content: Foreign intelligence services are increasingly targeting Germany, its domestic intelligence agency said on Tuesday, warning that espionage, cyberattacks and disinformation campaigns, particularly from China and Russia, “pose a serious threat” to the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cindy Kuzma
title: Tai Chi Is a Workout for the Brain and Body
description: The mental and physical benefits span cultures and generations. Here’s how to get started.
content: “Parting the Wild Horse’s Mane.” “Wave Hands Like Clouds.” “Embrace Tiger, Return to Mountain.” These are not song titles or poems. Rather, they’re the deceptively complex movements of tai chi.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erika Solomon
title: As German Anxieties About Future Rise, Far Right Party Profits
description: With Germans facing an era of political and economic turbulence, the Alternative for Germany is resurgent. Mainstream politicians are struggling to respond.
content: The tables were packed at the Waldhaus, a restaurant on the wooded outskirts of an east German town, as the regulars — workers shaking calloused hands, retirees clutching purses in their lap — settled in for a pub gathering of the far-right Alternative for Germany.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elie Levine
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: What the Heck Is Going on With These U.F.O. Stories?
description: Leslie Kean helped break the news of a whistle-blower who claims the government possesses materials from a craft of “nonhuman origin.” We discuss her reporting — and what remains unclear.
content: The New York Times Audio app includes podcasts, narrated articles from the newsroom and other publishers, as well as exclusive new shows — including this one — which we’re making available to readers for a limited time. Download the audio app here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola and Anushka Patil
title: British Explorer on Missing Submersible Said He Knew the Risk of Such Voyages
description: Hamish Harding, who had set a record on a mission to the deepest part of the ocean, said after that feat: “If something goes wrong, you are not coming back.”
content: Hamish Harding, a British explorer aboard the submersible missing in the North Atlantic, acknowledged in a 2021 interview that he had taken on deep-sea missions in the past knowing that rescue would not be an option.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The International Herald Tribune
title: 1948: Paris ‘Métro’ Gets New Name, But Subway-Goers Won’t Use It
description: With an eye toward expansion, the company in charge of the French capital’s transport system will be renamed.
content: The Paris subway company announced yesterday that in accordance with a vote taken at a shareholders’ meeting Friday it has changed its name from “Compagnie du Chemin de Fer Métropolitain de Paris” to “Société Générale de Traction et d’Exploitations.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anushka Patil and Jacey Fortin
title: Inside the Titan: Quiet and Cramped, With a Single Porthole
description: “You just drop like a stone for two and a half hours,” said a writer for “The Simpsons” who made the trip to the Titanic wreckage.
content: Passengers seeking a glimpse of the R.M.S. Titanic aboard the submersible that disappeared in the North Atlantic this week have endured hours in a dangerous drop to the ocean floor aboard a cramped craft with a single porthole.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aidan Gardiner
title: A New Study Paints a Different Picture of Homelessness in California
description: Researchers found that homeless people in California were often living in poverty within the state, until they suddenly lost their home.
content: There are a lot of myths about people who are homeless in California: They’re from another state. They don’t want a job. They don’t want a home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Cotter
title: The Best Place to Drink Is the Emptiest Bar in the City
description: When your hearing starts to go, you just want a place to sit, sip and have a talk: namely, a hotel bar.
content: I’m sipping a bitters and soda in an empty hotel bar — empty but for the mixologist, who’s pouring himself one finger, very deftly, of Pernod, then concealing it down by the sink. Soon my long-lost friend arrives, and the two of us will stay here at the bar for the evening. He looks around to make sure no one is listening — it’s clear as a bare stage. He warms to his story: a brother in trouble, red-pilled and creeping around at sinister rallies. I offer some cautions, some questions. Very naturally, we touch on my bad health. Which, as it happens, is why we’re talking here in a hotel bar. And why we’ll be here for hours to come, no plans to move on later to someplace brighter, or hipper, or darker — nowhere to see or be seen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Lipton
title: Trump Real Estate Deal in Oman Underscores Ethics Concerns
description: Details of the former president’s agreement to work with a Saudi firm to develop a hotel and golf complex overlooking the Gulf of Oman highlight the ways his business and political roles intersect.
content: On a remote site at the edge of the Gulf of Oman, thousands of migrant laborers from Bangladesh, India and Pakistan are at work in 103-degree heat, toiling in shifts from dawn until nightfall to build a new city, a multibillion-dollar project backed by Oman’s oil-rich government that has an unusual partner: former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: Take Bobby Kennedy Jr. Seriously, Not Literally
description: Could he be the Eugene McCarthy of 2024?
content: In 1968, Senator Eugene McCarthy challenged Lyndon Johnson for the Democratic presidential nomination and ran a close second in the New Hampshire primary. The near upset by McCarthy, a Minnesota progressive, helped convince Johnson that he should not run for re-election, opening the way for Robert F. Kennedy. History might have been very different if tragedy hadn’t intervened that June at the Ambassador Hotel in Los Angeles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexander Lobrano
title: Malta, Land of Knights, Sailors and Rainbow Flags
description: The Mediterranean island nation is gearing up to show off its history of openness, as well as its Baroque treasures, when it hosts EuroPride in September.
content: I was having a nightcap at the palmy, Art Deco Phoenicia Hotel in Valletta, Malta, when a former British naval officer struck up a chat, quickly confiding in me that he thought Prince Philip, Queen Elizabeth II’s husband, was the handsomest man he’d ever seen. The prince and the future monarch spent the early years of their marriage in Malta, the former base of the British Mediterranean fleet, where Philip was posted to a ship.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: Going Back in Time, M.L.B. Will Play a Game at Rickwood Field
description: The Birmingham, Ala., stadium was home to Willie Mays in his Negro leagues days. It will host a game between Mays’s Giants and the Cardinals in 2024.
content: Rickwood Field in Birmingham, Ala., believed to be the oldest professional baseball stadium in the United States, has played host to some of baseball’s greatest luminaries during its 113-year run, including Babe Ruth and Willie Mays, the latter of whom grew up a short distance from the park.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: Review: A Genderqueer ‘Cabaret,’ at War With Itself
description: A revival of the 1998 revisal of the 1966 musical highlights the stories of trans and nonbinary performers.
content: The revival of “Cabaret” that opened on Sunday at the Barrington Stage Company in Pittsfield, Mass., has a bad case of the Underwear Problem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Andrew Tate Indicted on Charges of Human Trafficking in Romania
description: Prosecutors in the country announced an indictment against the antagonistic online personality known for his misogynistic remarks. He had been under house arrest outside Bucharest.
content: Andrew Tate, an antagonistic online personality known for his misogyny, has been indicted in Romania on charges including human trafficking and forming an organized criminal group related to the abuse of women, prosecutors there said in a statement on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Leslie Kean
description: The June 20, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Leslie Kean. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliet Macur
title: U.S. Women’s World Cup Roster Will Reflect a Team in Transition
description: Form and injuries have affected the players available to Vlatko Andonovski as he picks a squad facing perhaps the toughest challenge in its history.
content: Here’s a sentence you see every four years: The United States is a favorite to win the Women’s World Cup.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elise Young
title: Improper Covid Aid Flowed to Fishery Businesses, Official Finds
description: Nearly half of $14.4 million dispensed to seafood processors, charter boats and other businesses in New Jersey during the pandemic may have to be paid back.
content: The New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection is pressing fishery businesses to pay back almost half of all their federal Covid-19 aid because it was improperly allocated, according to a letter from the state comptroller’s office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Friends, Tourists, Countrymen, See Where Julius Caesar Was Killed
description: The site where Caesar was assassinated by a group of senators in 44 B.C., nestled among four ancient temples, has been opened to the public for the first time in a century.
content: For nearly a century, only cats (and presumably the rats they kept at bay) had free rein over an ancient archaeological site in the heart of central Rome. They would prowl among the ruins and preen for the tourists who gathered along the balustrades above, cellphones and cameras in hand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘Surrounded’ Review: Letitia Wright Impresses in an Overbaked Western
description: Playing a woman disguising herself as a man, Wright is haunting and haunted, and Michael K. Williams is an energetic presence in one of his last roles.
content: Moses Washington, who goes by Mo, is a former Buffalo Soldier and freed slave seeking to make a new life in the post-Civil-War Wild West. Mo is also a woman disguising herself as a man; she’s played by Letitia Wright.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: Police Search Paris 2024 Olympics Offices in Corruption Investigation
description: French prosecutors said they were investigating potential conflicts of interest, embezzlement and favoritism connected to public contracts signed by organizers of the Games.
content: The French police searched the headquarters of the Paris 2024 Olympics organizing committee and other offices on Tuesday as part of two corruption investigations over contracts signed in connection with the Games, prosecutors said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Porter and Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Wednesday Briefing: The Search for the Missing Titanic Sub
description: Also, a shake-up at Alibaba and a taste of Singapore’s street food.
content: An international team of rescuers was racing against time to find a deep-diving submersible with five people on board after it lost contact in the North Atlantic during a tour to explore the wreck of the Titanic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Thousands of Reddit Communities Stay Dark as App Policy Protest Continues
description: Users’ anger continued to bubble over changes to the company’s business model.
content: Thousands of volunteer-run message boards on Reddit remained dark on Tuesday, a week after moderators of the communities began what they called a 48-hour protest against Reddit’s planned changes to its business model.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Delger Erdenesanaa
title: Himalayan Glacier Loss Speeding Up, New Report Finds
description: Glaciers in the region melted faster between 2010 and 2019 than in the previous decade. “Things are just happening so fast,” one researcher said.
content: New research from scientists in Nepal confirms that ice and snow in the world’s highest mountains are disappearing as a result of rising temperatures and at a faster pace than previously thought. The report from the International Centre for Integrated Mountain Development in Kathmandu finds that glaciers in the Hindu Kush and Himalaya mountain range region melted 65 percent faster from 2010 through 2019 than in the previous decade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer and Erin Nolan
title: 2 Arrested After a Fatal Stabbing and 3 Slashings on the Subway
description: The police added 80 officers to the subway system after a man was fatally stabbed and three women were slashed in the legs in separate attacks over the weekend.
content: After a series of assaults in the subways over the weekend — including a fatal stabbing of a man during a fight and attacks on three women who were slashed in the legs — the Police Department stepped up its presence in the system and arrested two men.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth A. Harris and Alexandra Alter
title: Authors and Students Sue Over Florida Law Driving Book Bans
description: The authors of a picture book about a penguin family with two fathers sued the state and a school district that removed the book from libraries.
content: A group of students and the authors of a children’s book about a penguin family with two fathers sued a Florida school district and the state’s board of education on Tuesday, saying that restricting access to the book in school libraries was unconstitutional.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nikita Richardson
title: The Black-Owned Restaurants of Bed-Stuy
description: Watching in real time as a neighborhood changes while trying to cling to its identity.
content: There’s nothing better than finding your neighborhood in New York City. The place where you feel the most comfortable in your skin, where you feel immersed in the community and held close by its warmth. For me, as a Black woman, that is Bed-Stuy, where I’ve lived since 2015.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘I Wore an Orange Wig’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: My oldest child and I drove from Massachusetts to New Hampshire to visit my father, who had suffered a stroke. It gave us a rare chance to catch up. After five hours of round trip travel in the car, I reached over to say goodbye. My eldest always saves the biggest news for the last moment. “You know how you have two sons?” my child asked, watching my face. “Now you have a daughter and son.” Confusion and questions swirled inside me. But only one response mattered. I held my daughter tightly, calling my child by her new name, Katy. — Linda Button
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: What Happens if a Presidential Candidate Is Convicted?
description: The Constitution and American law have clear answers for only some of the questions that would arise. Others would bring the country into truly uncharted territory.
content: Not since Eugene V. Debs campaigned from a prison cell more than a century ago has the United States experienced what might now happen: a prominent candidate with a felony conviction running for president. And never before has that candidate been someone with a real chance of winning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chang Che
title: In Overhaul, Alibaba’s Boss Moves Aside and Two Co-Founders Step Up
description: The Chinese tech giant says its top leader, Daniel Zhang, will make way for two long-serving executives: Joseph Tsai takes over as chairman and Eddie Yongming Wu becomes chief executive.
content: In late March, Daniel Zhang unveiled what was called the “most significant” overhaul in the 24-year history of Alibaba, one of China’s original technology conglomerates, splitting the company into six units that would help them seek out investors from the public.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: ‘Secret Invasion’ Review: Marvel Welcomes Back Samuel L. Jackson
description: Nick Fury gets back in the fight in the latest Disney+ series from the Marvel assembly line.
content: The folks at Disney sent critics only two episodes of the new Marvel mini-series “Secret Invasion,” which is one more than we sometimes get from the Fortress of Spoilertude. (Apologies for the mixed corporate metaphors.)
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Trump Ties Money and Politics Into Oman Deal
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, June 20, 2023.
content: “It is the kind of corruption our founding fathers most worried about.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Walther
title: What America Could Learn From ‘Skip and Shannon: Undisputed’
description: It’s no surprise that this sports talk show is an indispensable source of chatter about sports. What’s weird is how good it is at talking about politics and race.
content: As a self-conscious recusant from the so-called prestige TV revolution, I take a certain knowing delight in telling people that the only show — broadcast or streaming — that I watch is “Skip and Shannon: Undisputed,” a daily morning talk program on FS1, Fox’s national sports channel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas and Emily Cochrane
title: Judge Strikes Down Arkansas Law Banning Gender Transition Care for Minors
description: The case had been closely watched as an important test of whether bans on transition care for minors, enacted by more than a dozen states, could withstand challenges.
content: A federal judge in Arkansas on Tuesday struck down the state’s law forbidding medical treatments for children and teenagers seeking gender transitions, blocking what had been the first in a wave of such measures championed by conservative lawmakers across the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kristen Arnett
title: Can You Still Be a Femme Fatale if You’re Butch?
description: The protagonist of K. Patrick’s “Mrs. S,” a boarding school worker questioning her gender expression, falls into a torrid affair with the headmaster’s wife.
content: When we think of bodies in fiction, we generally consider them in relation to other objects or other people. Characters glance in a mirror to examine their features and we’re allowed a brief glimpse of cheekbone, jawline or eye color. Are they tall or short? Nondescript or peculiar? Lanky-limbed or compact and muscular, like a stout pony? We understand how a body moves through a narrative because we’ve received a set of keys and instructions for how to operate the vehicle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Is Taylor Swift Underpaid?
description: Superstars in historical perspective.
content: Like almost every other nation, Sweden has been experiencing high inflation recently. Consumer prices have risen 9.7 percent over the past year, reflecting multiple factors: large spending to support households during the pandemic, Covid-related disruptions of supply chains, Russia’s invasion of Ukraine and Beyoncé.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: Paul-Henri Nargeolet Has Made More Than 35 Titanic Site Trips
description: Mr. Nargeolet, a French maritime expert, is one of the five people aboard the missing submersible. He works for RMS Titanic, which owns the salvage rights to the wreck.
content: Paul-Henri Nargeolet, a French maritime expert who has been on over 35 dives to the Titanic wreck site, is one of the five people aboard the submersible that has been missing since Sunday, according to his literary representative, Mathieu Johann.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: The Suburbs Don’t Love New York
description: As fewer suburbanites commute to the city, their fear and loathing has grown, as have tensions between city and suburban officials.
content: Good morning. We’ll look at why New York City and the surrounding suburban jurisdictions are increasingly at odds. We’ll also follow up on the story of the famous wine store that is accused of failing to deliver more than $1 million in orders to customers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emiliano Rodríguez Mega and Joan Suazo
title: 41 Dead After Riot Erupts in Honduran Women’s Prison
description: The inmates were found shot or burned to death in the latest spasm of violence in the country’s troubled prison system.
content: At least 41 inmates were killed on Tuesday morning in central Honduras after a riot broke out at the country’s only prison for women, one of the deadliest outbreaks of violence in the country’s long-troubled prison system.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: How ‘Backlash’ Explains America
description: Times columnists chose the TV shows, movies, books and songs that capture the country as they see it.
content: Times columnists chose the TV shows, movies, books and songs that capture the country as they see it.

title: Behind the Scenes of Padma Lakshmi’s “Taste the Nation”

title: How ‘Rapper’s Delight’ Explains America
description: Times columnists chose the TV shows, movies, books and songs that capture the country as they see it.

title: Taylor Swift, Maestro of Pop, Returns to the Stage

description: Times columnists chose the TV shows, movies, books and songs that capture the country as they see it.

title: How ‘Invasion of the Body Snatchers’ Explains America
description: Times columnists chose the TV shows, movies, books and songs that capture the country as they see it.

author: By Tressie McMillan Cottom
title: How ‘Ted Lasso’ Explains America
description: Times columnists chose the TV shows, movies, books and songs that capture the country as they see it.
content: Times columnists chose the TV shows, movies, books and songs that capture the country as they see it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrina Miller
title: The Summer Solstice Is Here. What’s New With Our Sun?
description: As the Northern Hemisphere tilts toward the sun, let's check in on everything that's happening with our home star.
content: As the Northern Hemisphere tilts toward the sun, let's check in on everything that's happening with our home star.
